notes: To begin creating your project, use the Images module to compile a list of files and/or folders that you want to analyze. You can also specify a set of rules to include only the desired files in your selected folders.
Drag and drop your IMAGES (you can drag and drop the entire "images_Illum-corrected" folder) into the panel just below this one.
<-Drag and drop your "segmentation_start.cppipe" files into the left panel.
FOR THIS TUTORIAL, YOU CAN SKIP THIS MODULE, AS IT IS ALREADY CONFIGURED.

The Metadata module optionally allows you to extract information describing your images (i.e, metadata) which will be stored along with your measurements. This information can be contained in the file name and/or location, or in an external file.

settings.name: cellprofiler_core.setting._regexp_text.RegexpText
settings.text: Regular expression to extract from file name

settings.name: cellprofiler_core.setting._regexp_text.RegexpText
settings.text: Regular expression to extract from folder name

notes: FOR THIS TUTORIAL, YOU CAN SKIP THIS MODULE, AS IT IS ALREADY CONFIGURED.
The NamesAndTypes module allows you to assign a meaningful name to each image by which other modules will refer to it.
FOR THIS TUTORIAL, YOU CAN SKIP THIS MODULE, AS IT IS NOT USED.

The Groups module optionally allows you to split your list of images into image subsets (groups) which will be processed independently of each other. Examples of groupings include screening batches, microtiter plates, time-lapse movies, etc.

settings.name: cellprofiler_core.setting._binary.Binary
settings.text: Do you want to group your images?

notes: This module is used to create a group of objects called Nuclei by segmenting the nuclear regions from the OrigDNA image.
The settings used here should be good enough for the images used in this tutorial but they depend highly on the image set!
We encourage you to play around with the settings in order to get a "good enough" segmentation of your own data.
REMEMBER: we aim for "good enough" because there is no settings that will give you a PERFECT segmentation every time in every image.

notes: This module is used to create a group of objects called Cells by segmenting the celular regions from the OrigActin_Golgi_Membrane image.
To help with this, this module takes the Nuclei objects created in the previous module as input, to use them as references for building the Cells objects.
We encourage you to play around with the settings in order to get a "good enough" segmentation of your own data.
REMEMBER: we aim for "good enough" because there is no settings that will give you a PERFECT segmentation every time in every image.

notes: This module creates a set of Cytoplasm objects by simply subtracting the Nuclei objects from their corresponding Cells objects.

settings.name: cellprofiler_core.setting.text.alphanumeric.name._label_name.LabelName
settings.text: Name the tertiary objects to be identified

settings.name: cellprofiler_core.setting._binary.Binary
settings.text: Shrink smaller object prior to subtraction?

notes: Now we want to segment nucleoli from the OrigRNA image, but the nuclear RNA spots (which are the nucleoli) are not contrasted enough with their nuclear background.
This module processes the OrigRNA image and enhances "speckly" shapes of a certain size, producing a new image called FilteredRNA.
In the FilteredRNA image, not only the nuclear RNA spots have been enhanced, but also the cytoplasmic ones (which are NOT nucleoli)!!
This module will mask the FilteredRNA image using the Nuclei objects so that any pixel outside of the Nuclei becomes 0 (thus, ridding us of the cytoplasmic RNA spots).
The resulting masked image is named RNA_in_Nuclei.

settings.name: cellprofiler_core.setting.choice._choice.Choice
settings.text: Use objects or an image as a mask?

notes: This module is used to create a group of objects called Nucleoli by segmenting the RNA spots from the RNA_in_Nuclei image.

notes: This module produces a visualization of our segmentations so far by overlaying the Nuclei and Nucleoli objects outlines onto the OrigRNA image.
This is useful both as a sanity check and as a means of showing theresults of your analysis to others!
The output of this module is called SanityCheck.

settings.name: cellprofiler_core.setting._binary.Binary
settings.text: Display outlines on a blank image?

notes: This module will measure a series of intensity metrics within each selected object on all selected images.
This module will measure the area and a series of shaped-related metrics of each selected object.
Measures the colocalization and correlation between intensities in your different images on a pixel-by-pixel basis, within identified objects or across an entire image.

settings.text: Calculate the Manders coefficients using Costes auto threshold?

notes: This module relates a larger "Parent object" to another smaller "Child object/s". In this case, this allows us to identify which Nucleoli belong to which Nuclei.
The output is a new object called NucleoliChildObjects that has all of the nucleoli belonging to a single nucleus

settings.name: cellprofiler_core.setting._binary.Binary

settings.text: Do you want to save the children with parents as a new object set?

notes: This module saves the SanityCheck images for future reference. It does so in a sub-folder of the default output folder called "overlay-images".
Tha name of the saved file is constructed using the name of the corresponding OrigRNA image as a prefix and adding a "_overlay" suffix.
